title: PolitiFact - No, 'Denali' is not a Kenyan word for 'black power'
subtitle: Critics of President Barack Obama’s decision to drop President William McKinley as the namesake of America’s tallest mou
author: www.politifact.com
vclaim:
Critics of President Barack Obama’s decision to drop President William McKinley as the namesake of America’s tallest mountain say the move is insulting to a great president from Ohio.

Anonymous social media critics point to a more hidden motive in the mountain’s new name, Denali.

One image circulating on Facebook accused the president of reaching back to his Kenyan roots for inspiration, claiming that " ‘Denali’ is the Kenyan word for ‘black power.’ "

The meme’s claim is so ridiculous that you wonder if it’s just a bad joke.

To start, "Kenyan" is not a language. The two official languages of Kenya are English and Swahili. Neither of those languages are exclusive to one country, as Swahili is also spoken in a number of different African nations.

A search of turned up no results for the word "Denali."

As our fact-checker friends at Snopes , the Swahili word for " " is "mweusi," and the Swahili word for is "nguvu."

That doesn’t amount to "Denali," which has roots in the word "Deenaalee" in Koyukon, a currently spoken by . Koyukon is part of the Athabaskan language family, which also includes Navajo and several Apache languages native to the American Southwest.

"Deenaalee" to "the High One," according to James Fall, an official at Alaska’s Department of Fish and Game, and James Kari, a linguist at the University of Alaska Fairbanks’ Native Language Center.

Obama the name change "a step to reflect the heritage of Alaska Natives."

While the meme’s claim is ridiculous, we were able to verify that the viral image does depict .

The meme claims " ‘Denali’ is the Kenyan word for ‘black power.’ "

The word "Denali" doesn’t show up in Swahili, one of Kenya’s two national languages. Instead, it’s Koyukon Athabaskan for "high" or "tall."

We rate the meme’s claim Pants on Fire!
